com.esri.mo2.file.shp
Class ShpFile

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.esri.mo2.file.shp.ShpFile
public class ShpFile
extends Object

This class manages the geometry component of a shapefile. This component is represented by two files. The geometry data is stored in a file with an extension of "shp". The lookup data, which is used to randomly access the file, is stored in a file with the extension of "shx". All references to "SHP", in the remainder of this document, refer to both of these files.

When using this class to create a shapefile, it is important to remember that each shapefile must also contain an attribute component as well. The DbfFile class can be used to provide this functionality. For every record added to the SHP file, there must also be a corresponding record added to the DBF file.

When using this class to read a shapefile, it is not necessary to access the attribute component of the shapefile unless you need to read the attribute values.

All SHP files share a common structure. The only difference between one shapefile type and another is the information that is actually stored in each record. As a result, two classes must be used to properly manage a SHP file. The ShpFile class manages the common structure of an SHP file. This class provides methods to open, close, create, read, and write SHP files. The ShpRecord class manages the data that is actually stored within the record. This class provides methods to access the geometric data from the record.

The following code snippet shows how to use the ShpFile, ShpRecord and PointShp classes to create the geometry component of a point shapefile. The resulting file will contain 25 records with one point per record. Please note that this example also creates a corresponding attribute component for the shapefile.

DbfField dbffield; DbfFile dbffile; DbfRecord dRec; double x; double y; int i; int nRecs; PointShp pointshp; Random rn; ShpFile shpfile; ShpRecord sRec; try { //setup geometry component shpfile= new ShpFile("point.shp"); shpfile.openNew(ShapeTypes.POINT); //setup attribute component dbffile= new DbfFile("point.dbf"); dbffile.openNew(); dbffield= DbfField.create("REC_ID",Types.INTEGER,5,0); dbffile.addField(dbffield); rn= new Random(); nRecs=25; for (i=1; i<=nRecs; i++) { //write geometry component sRec= shpfile.createRecord(); pointshp= (PointShp)sRec.getValue(0); x= rn.nextDouble() * 25.0; y= rn.nextDouble() * 25.0; pointshp.setNumPoints(1); pointshp.setXAt(0,x); pointshp.setYAt(0,y); sRec.setValue(0,pointshp); shpfile.putRecord(sRec); //write attribute component dRec= dbffile.createRecord(); dRec.setValue(0,new Long((long)i)); dbffile.putRecord(dRec); if (sRec.getStatus()==ShpRecord.OK && dRec.getStatus()==DbfRecord.OK) System.out.println("record "+i+" written ok"); else { if (sRec.getStatus()!=ShpRecord.OK) System.out.println("shp data has an error"); if (dRec.getStatus()!=DbfRecord.OK) System.out.println("dbf data has an error"); } } shpfile.close(); dbffile.close(); } catch (Exception e) { System.out.println("exception thrown"); }

The following code snippet shows how to use the ShpFile, ShpRecord, and PolylineShp classes to create the geometry component of a multipart shapefile. This snippet creates a polyline shp file with 14 records. Each record will contain between 1 and 5 parts. Each part will contain between 2 and 4 points. Please note that this example also creates a corresponding attribute component for the shapefile.

DbfField dbffield; DbfFile dbffile; DbfRecord dRec; double[] x,y; int i,j,k; int nParts,nPoints,nRecs; PolylineShp polylineShp; Random rn; ShpFile shpfile; ShpRecord sRec; try { //setup geometry component shpfile= new ShpFile("polyline.shp"); shpfile.openNew(ShapeTypes.POLYLINE); //setup attribute component dbffile= new DbfFile("polyline.dbf"); dbffile.openNew(); dbffield= DbfField.create("PARTS",Types.INTEGER,5,0); dbffile.addField(dbffield); nRecs=14; rn= new Random(); for (i=1; i<=nRecs; i++) { //write geometry component sRec= shpfile.createRecord(); polylineShp= (PolylineShp)sRec.getValue(0); nParts= rn.nextInt(5) + 1; polylineShp.setNumParts(nParts); for (j=0; j<nParts; j++) { nPoints= rn.nextInt(2) + 2; polylineShp.setNumPoints(j,nPoints); x= new double[nPoints]; y= new double[nPoints]; for (k=0; k<nPoints; k++) { x[k]= rn.nextDouble() * 100.0; y[k]= rn.nextDouble() * 100.0; } polylineShp.setX(j,x); polylineShp.setY(j,y); } sRec.setValue(0,polylineShp); shpfile.putRecord(sRec); //write attribute component dRec= dbffile.createRecord(); dRec.setValue(0,new Long((long)nParts)); dbffile.putRecord(dRec); if (sRec.getStatus()==ShpRecord.OK && dRec.getStatus()==DbfRecord.OK) System.out.println("record "+i+" written ok"); else System.out.println("record "+i+" has an error"); if (sRec.getStatus()!=ShpRecord.OK) System.out.println("shp data has an error"); if (dRec.getStatus()!=DbfRecord.OK) System.out.println("dbf data has an error"); } shpfile.close(); dbffile.close(); } catch (Exception e) { System.out.println("exception thrown"); }

The following code snippet shows how to use the ShpFile, ShpRecord, and MultiPointShp classes to read all of the records of a multipoint shp file. Please note that a multipoint shape may contain 1 or more points per record. Please also note that this example does not access the attribute component of the shapefile.

double[] x,y; int i,nRecs,nPnts; MultiPointShp multipointShp; ShpFile shpfile; ShpRecord sRec; try { shpfile= new ShpFile("multipoint.shp"); shpfile.openExisting(); switch (shpfile.getFileType()) { case ShapeTypes.MULTIPOINT: case ShapeTypes.MULTIPOINTM: case ShapeTypes.MULTIPOINTZ: break; default: System.out.println("this is not a multipoint file"); return; } nRecs= shpfile.getNumRecs(); System.out.println("there are "+nRecs+" records"); for (i=1; i<=nRecs; i++) { sRec= shpfile.getRecord(null,i); if (sRec.getStatus()!=ShpRecord.OK) { System.out.println("record "+i+" has an error"); continue; } multipointShp= (MultiPointShp)sRec.getValue(0); if (multipointShp.isNull()) { System.out.println("record "+i+" contains a null shape"); continue; } nPnts= multipointShp.getNumPoints(); System.out.println("record "+i+" has "+nPnts+" points"); x= multipointShp.getX(); y= multipointShp.getY(); } shpfile.close(); } catch (Exception e) { System.out.println("exception thrown"); }

The following code snippet shows how to use the ShpFile, ShpRecord and PolygonShp classes to read all of the records of a multipart shp file. This snippet reads polygon shp files. Please note that a polygon shape may contain 1 or more parts. In addition, each part may contain 4 or more points. Please also note that this example does not access the attribute component of the shapefile.

double[] x,y; int i,j; int nParts,nRecs; PolygonShp polygonShp; ShpFile shpfile; ShpRecord sRec; try { shpfile= new ShpFile("polygon.shp"); shpfile.openExisting(); switch (shpfile.getFileType()) { case ShapeTypes.POLYGON: case ShapeTypes.POLYGONM: case ShapeTypes.POLYGONZ: break; default: System.out.println("this is not a polygon file"); return; } nRecs= shpfile.getNumRecs(); System.out.println("there are "+nRecs+" records in the file"); for (i=1; i<=nRecs; i++) { sRec= shpfile.getRecord(null,i); if (sRec.getStatus()!=ShpRecord.OK) { System.out.println("record "+i+" has an error"); continue; } polygonShp= (PolygonShp)sRec.getValue(0); if (polygonShp.isNull()) { System.out.println("record "+i+" contains a null shape"); continue; } nParts= polygonShp.getNumParts(); System.out.println("record "+i+" has "+nParts+" parts"); for (j=0; j<nParts; j++) { //get the points for each part x= polygonShp.getX(j); y= polygonShp.getY(j); } } shpfile.close(); } catch (Exception e) { System.out.println("exception thrown"); }

delRecord

public int delRecord(int rec)
Deletes the specified record. More specifically, the record is marked as deleted. While this will not actually remove the record from the file, the record will be considered to be deleted by all getRecord() methods.

Parameters:
rec - record number
Returns:
ShpRecord status code
